12.45.text:
They were absolutely, l think,
the best band of the day.

15.28.text:
They played the best,
they had the best sound,

17.78.text:
they used their 1 7 minutes
or whatever to the best.

20.42.text: l mean, they understood the idea exactly.

22.82.text:
This was a very unique event, and people say
that we were so good, in terms of

28.40.text:
all the creme de la creme of the music world,
so that's quite an achievement.

32.73.text:
Elton came up and said,
"You stole the show!"

37.37.text:
Or something like that.
l thought he was being nice, you know?

40.07.text:
lt wasn't another gig at all. ln fact, l had
a really bad attack of nerves in the morning

43.94.text:
because of the TV, and you knew
it was being satellited everywhere.

47.25.text:
l've seldom been so nervous,
in fact, probably never.

50.05.text:
But l think it was
the greatest day of our lives,

52.39.text:
even though we played
only a very small part.

54.29.text:
lt's the thing
l'll remember above all in our career.

59.06.text:
lt sort of injected some new fuel
into our bodies, you know?

62.83.text:
We had actually planned on taking
the rest of that year off completely.

66.87.text:
A few weeks later, Freddie was on the phone,
and he wanted to go back in the studio

73.14.text:
ln fact, l was late
getting to the recording sessions

76.14.text: 'cause l was actually on holiday at the time.

79.05.text:
Financially, they have
no need to continue to work.

82.72.text:
They have no need to continue to go
through the traumas of working,

85.82.text:
which it is, with the four
very strong characters you have.

88.49.text:
There seems to be no desire at all
to put up their feet and rest.

109.34.text:
The band has always come first, actually,
and anything else, really, outside Queen,

117.28.text:
l enjoy working.
l don't like long periods of inactivity.

131.13.text:
Our next project is the film Highlander,
which is produced by Russell Mulcahy.

145.25.text:
The film needs,
not only a big orchestration score,

149.12.text:
but it needs a big rock score of that
anthem-type quality that they're famous for.

156.22.text:
And so l had 20 minutes of the film
cut together and l brought them in,

160.03.text:
and l didn't know how
they were going to react.

170.40.text:
l think he said that he had us in mind
at one point early on. We initially said, "No,"

174.87.text:
and then we saw that 20 minutes cut
of this Highlander film, and thought,

181.78.text:
l only wanted them
to do one song in the film.

184.48.text:
They saw the footage,
and they said, "We'll do five songs."

187.42.text:
We found plenty of things in the plot
to jump off on, you know,

194.26.text:
Princes of the Universe,
which is about the people, not about us,

197.56.text:
it's about the people in the film,
who are immortal.

201.67.text:
We shot that video using bits of the film,
but we sort of integrated the two

206.64.text: by using Chris Lambert, and so he sort of...

210.78.text:
He's in the film, then he suddenly strolls,
and he's on stage with us.

223.86.text:
Main plot is this kind of violent tale
of immortals fighting each other to the death.

227.96.text:
There's a kind of sub-plot,
which is a tragic love story,

231.23.text:
and it comes about because the hero
cannot die, so he falls in love with this girl

234.47.text:
in the highlands, and she gradually
grows old and dies in his arms.

237.80.text:
And he has to say goodbye to her,
and he has to go on.

240.11.text:
And that really came across to me
very strongly, and l related it to my own life,

247.75.text:
l thought, "Love always does
come to an end, at some time."

250.55.text:
And so l had this song
immediately in my head,

252.69.text: which is called Who Wants to Live Forever?

293.46.text:
l ended up writing a slow ballad,
which is called One Year of Love,

297.63.text:
and that goes when he eventually decides
to have another relationship

301.33.text:
with a woman again,
'cause he vowed he never would again,

303.40.text: 'cause it hurt him so much the first time.

336.20.text:
l think if l'd just been, say, a bass player
all my life, you know, with the band,

341.31.text:
it wouldn't be so satisfying to sit here now,
and that would have been my input.

345.28.text:
l only consider that as part of what l do.
And then, you know, actually writing songs

350.42.text:
and also being involved
in the decision-making processes,

354.39.text:
or arguments, or whatever,
is nice, you know?

358.46.text:
lt really feels that you're part of
our own destiny, really.

362.96.text: l mean, John's been writing quite a lot now,

364.80.text:
and he just writes
in that one area which he likes.

367.10.text:
And l love that,
because l love to sing on songs like that.

369.40.text:
Brian writes from the guitar,
so we have that element,

372.74.text:
and then Roger, l think,
writes from the drums.

375.38.text: He sort of crosses over a lot.

377.21.text: So we have all kinds of things.

378.98.text:
l think we're all still trying to use this beast
which Queen is as a vehicle

382.38.text:
to get our own ideas across. And we all
write very different kinds of songs,

386.89.text:
and it's quite a challenge to get them
through this machinery and get them out.

391.22.text:
lf l write a song which has a particular idea
behind it, and l can hear it in my head,

395.56.text:
l then go take it to the other three, and they
all see it totally differently and want to do it

399.30.text:
in a different way. And some of their input
will be very good and very necessary,

403.74.text:
and some of it will probably, actually,
destroy the meaning of the song.

406.64.text:
So there's all this interaction going on
all the time.

409.21.text:
Most of our songs are developed
in the studio these days.

411.81.text:
Whereas before,
we used to have routining time,

414.45.text: so we used to try and write our songs...

417.08.text:
But l think, these days,
there's no time for anything.

418.99.text:
So, l mean, we just book studio time
and we just go in there.

421.82.text:
Freddie certainly adopts a very different
persona within the band

426.23.text:
as opposed to when they're performing.
Freddie is often a very compromising force,

431.26.text:
in terms of the healthy rows,
and that really is what it's about.

435.97.text:
l think that so much of the success of Queen
has been the openness of the rows

440.91.text:
lf we make these harmonies, then we've got
another two-part harmony coming in, then...

444.61.text: l haven't got anything to sing!

446.61.text:
Might as well
just be a fucking Andrews Sister.

Roger's track, which is Magic,

But l just felt that there was
another commercial streak,

488.49.text:
and l just realised that he was going away

492.29.text:
so l just got hold of it,
and l just changed it around completely,

494.46.text:
and when he came back, l said,
"Well, what do you think?"

524.29.text:
John, you're here, of course, to promote
the new single, A Kind of Magic.

527.59.text:
-You look kind of strange on that video.
-l was dressed as a tramp, really. Yeah.

The Kind of Magic video was actually

535.40.text:
because we did it in a disused theatre,

538.20.text:
or any sort of background,

But the money will be spent on doing

l think the idea of a complete soundtrack

l think they're imagining
sort of all sorts of orchestral links,

561.73.text:
which don't really do anything, it's really just

are songs in their own right,

-You did what? Six songs for the movie?

there's six songs from the movie,

590.26.text:
There's an inward jealousy all the way
through our history,

593.66.text:
and that's what Queen albums
have been made of.

596.40.text:
And there's this push
and there's this hunger,

599.13.text:
and there's this sort of fight
to get the best songs out.

601.93.text:
They're a tremendous challenge.
They've always been very demanding,

604.60.text:
demanded perfection, all four of them.
Which is a great thing to work for,

608.64.text:
because there's a response then
if perfection comes through.

628.49.text:
The thing we're all looking forward to most
at the moment is this European tour.

632.83.text:
And that's quite a commitment from us,
in a way, really,

637.27.text:
because Freddie's sometimes a little
reluctant to go on the road these days.

640.01.text: lt's been a while since we actually did a tour.

644.04.text:
lt's very, very exhausting for me
to do what l have to do.

648.85.text: Stages are getting bigger and everything,

650.28.text:
and l just like to feel that l'm perfectly
fit to do these shows,

654.35.text: and not to just sort of say, "Yes, l'll do it."

657.06.text:
We're starting on it now, really, ideas for the
staging and lighting and that sort of thing.

661.23.text:
This particular tour you're doing,
you're taking a 1 60-foot stage,

664.46.text:
which is the biggest
ever constructed for rock?

667.20.text:
Yes, it's an absolutely massive stage.
lt's really been designed

669.44.text:
to cope with the places that we're playing in,
to get the optimum out of those places.

673.54.text:
We usually go in some place like
a film studio, which has this big, open...

677.48.text:
Like an aircraft hangar space,
and just set everything up,

695.06.text:
'Cause it's not enough for us
to be rehearsed,

697.00.text:
we make sure every single lamp,
every wire, is set up.

699.23.text:
So everything's gonna be given
a run-through,

701.50.text:
so all the bugs can be ironed out before
we get on tour. lt's like a full dress rehearsal.

706.47.text: We've been playing for so many years now,

707.64.text:
we do feel very relaxed
playing quite big gigs as well, really.

718.52.text:
Strange enough,
when you're used to large audiences,

722.32.text:
1 00,000 is almost less terrifying,
in some ways, than 5,000.

742.74.text:
lt's a strange thing with our band, the bigger
the audience, the better it seems to work.

748.28.text:
The audience contact seems to be better
with the larger audiences.

759.46.text:
Once you're on tour, l like to get on and do it.
l don't like to be hanging around on tour.

763.63.text:
l like to get in as much as you can,
because you can build up this great rhythm,

767.43.text:
and you get into the mood
and the feel of playing,

769.50.text: and you play better each night, l think.

771.30.text:
lf you see us at the end of the tour,
we're a lot different from what we are

774.01.text:
at the beginning of the tour,
it's 'cause we're in that rhythm.

776.41.text:
l suppose it's almost like being an athlete.
You just work on yourself,

779.15.text:
and you have nothing else to think about
except doing your bit for that two hours

828.89.text:
There was a trend a few years ago,
with the punk movement, or whatever,

832.03.text:
and they said,
"We want to play to the small audiences

835.94.text:
"'cause we're being intimate," and all that.
Load of rubbish.

839.27.text:
Everybody who wants to be a star
wants to play to the biggest audiences.

The fans were in Slane
to enjoy six hours of music.

847.75.text:
the main attraction, Queen,
arrived backstage by helicopter.

about showers beforehand, so most people
had anoraks and umbrellas.

Wearing his crown, lead singer Freddie
Mercury appeared out of a puff of smoke.

895.49.text:
l want to play to as many people as l can.
The bigger the better.

904.20.text:
Thirty-eight thousand people snapped up
tickets within days of them going on sale

908.07.text:
to see the first English concert
of Queen's European tour.

911.84.text:
Lads have been going past saying,
"Any tickets for sale? Any tickets for sale?"

918.58.text:
Queen have made the Newcastle concert
a charity event.

921.35.text:
The Save the Children fund should benefit by
about £50,000 from tonight's concert.

951.82.text:
We've been away a long time, and the tickets
will go on sale for Wembley on Friday.

958.62.text:
And it's always a time where you sort of go,
"l wonder what is out there?

961.86.text:
"l wonder if they still do want to see us?"
You know, you never know.

967.20.text:
And we'll only know once the applications
start coming in.

1002.10.text:
We can't just go out and play now. Say,
"We'll do this number, we'll do that number."

1006.41.text:
l mean, obviously, there's certain numbers
that we have to play. The bigger hits.

1017.82.text:
But choosing from the rest of them
is quite difficult. lt really is quite difficult.

1022.49.text:
And, you know, there are some numbers
that we've forgotten what key it's in.

1027.03.text:
Because we've got such a vast amount
of material over the years,

1030.66.text:
we actually do forget
some of our older numbers.

1035.27.text:
lt's so difficult, because when we make
an album, there are a lot of songs that

1038.77.text:
are very hard to play on stage. They don't
really automatically fall into a visual element.

1045.14.text:
And so, sometimes, a lot
of very good songs are not done on stage

1049.28.text: because we just feel they're not right.

1051.62.text:
l think there's only one country
that you've never been to before.

1056.42.text:
-Yeah, Budapest.
-So that is new ground, even in this...

1058.86.text:
lt's great!
Yeah, we're very excited about that.

There are people from all over
the lron Curtain bloc coming.

1066.27.text:
Or whatever they do over there.

There are people coming
from Poland and Czechoslovakia

1074.81.text:
and a lot of the Eastern Bloc,

1078.94.text: 'Cause the Russians would never let us in.

1089.19.text:
'Cause some places that we've already

l want to see the Queen concert,

1138.30.text:
Hungary is one of the more open countries
of the Eastern Bloc.

1141.54.text:
And bestriding the Danube,
its capital, Budapest,

1144.08.text: has the beginnings of a mixed economy.

1146.48.text:
Nevertheless, the familiar music
is of the classical variety.

1150.18.text:
And the arrival of rock, with its million-dollar
paycheques, a relatively new phenomenon.

A party to celebrate drummer Roger Taylor's
37th birthday took place

1163.10.text:
in Freddie's presidential suite,
at a princely cost of £5,000.

1175.27.text:
But what does Queen
get out of a visit to Hungary?

1179.01.text:
There's no profit to be made.
l mean, that's not the idea at all.

1182.28.text:
l mean, it's impossible to make a profit.
There's a tremendous feeling of...

1187.35.text:
l suppose "job satisfaction"
is a strange way to put it.

1192.12.text:
lt's quite good to get job satisfaction
after 14 years.

1195.36.text: Well, it's a pretty good job, isn't it?

And interview-shy Mercury
faced the Hungarian cameras.

1201.47.text:
So as the beginning of your friendship
with Hungary and with Budapest

1206.27.text:
and it may last long,
as long as Queen will last.

1209.98.text:
-lf l'm still alive, l will come back.

1217.38.text:
That's great.
l wish all interviews were that short.

1220.99.text:
State record shops had a limited supply
of the recent Queen album,

1224.52.text:
pressed under licence in Yugoslavia.
The Hungarians are record-mad.

1228.93.text:
Local bands can sell half a million albums.
But Queen are aiming to break into

1233.13.text:
the whole Eastern Bloc market
of 300 million potential record buyers.

1238.70.text:
The other incentive is a feature film
of the concert,

1241.44.text:
made by a group including
the state film corporation,

1244.51.text:
which mobilised 1 7 cameras
to shoot 25 miles of film of the concert

1249.68.text:
at a fraction of the cost
of a similar venture in the West.

1253.15.text:
This will be released
throughout the East this autumn.

1256.96.text:
As the crowd awaited Queen's arrival,
there were the usual warm-up bands.

So, after that lesson in stage presentation
from Hungary's ZiZi Labor,

1280.11.text:
it only remained for Queen
to try and compete.

And the ever self-effacing Freddie Mercury

Queen provided quieter moments,

and delighted the audience with some bars

The Hungarian fans responded like

And were treated to a final glimpse
of Freddie laying claim

l should add, that's the part of my role.

l just feel that...

The Queen Magic Tour began
two months ago in Stockholm. lt ends here.

Rock concerts have been held at Knebworth
since 1 972, always supported and enjoyed

1422.65.text: by the Lytton Cobbold family themselves.

The concert reached its climax

1458.19.text:
determined to enjoy themselves on this,
the last date of their European tour.

1488.49.text:
We always believed
that we had something special,

1490.89.text:
and that we could do anything
that anyone else did, this kind of thing,

1493.43.text:
that's the kind of belief
that kept us going in the early days.

1496.36.text:
But l don't think we quite
believed what would happen.

1499.30.text:
l don't think we even
knew what was possible.

1501.80.text:
l think that, in some form or another,
the music will always continue now.

1506.64.text:
l think they've reached that status
that their music will be remembered.

1511.31.text:
How much longer they record?
Goodness only knows.

1515.58.text:
Nobody knows whether Mick Jagger
will be singing when he's 65,

1519.75.text: or Queen will be performing as Queen.

1521.59.text:
l think that the Queen structure
will continue on.

1527.23.text:
And they will continue to make music.

1533.67.text:
We're the only set of four grandes dames

1543.88.text:
Yes, you do ask how long it's going to go on.

1548.71.text: And l don't know. l really...

lf l could tell the future,
